title: Surveying Employment Practices of Multinationals in Comparative Context: Integrating and Differentiating National Systems
abstractText:
Multinational companies (MNCs) have major effects on employment practices across countries.This research involved the construction and analysis of a unique international dataset in order to enhance our understanding of these effects by going beyond, but not dispensing with, the focus on the global-local tension that dominates studies of MNCs.

It did so by exploring three lines of analysis:

  • how we can explain variation in the influence of a particular home country on MNC behaviour
  • the link between the different forms of international integration and HR strategy
  • the roles of national subsidiaries of MNCs in shaping patterns of cross-border diffusion of practices.

The UK team is the founding member of INTREPID, an international network conducting parallel surveys of MNCs and employment practice across initially four countries: Canada, Ireland, Spain as well as the UK. The surveys are distinctive from previous studies in the lengths to which each has gone in establishing and screening the population of MNCs, making them the most comprehensive investigations in each country. They were closely coordinated, presenting the opportunity to shed unprecedented light on the crucial, yet poorly understood, role of MNCs as employers in the global economy.
